title: Deploying your application
Make sure you are in the directory that contains your Rails app, then create an app on Heroku.

inline_content.Text: Make sure you are in the directory that contains your Rails app, then create an app on Heroku.

title:
$ heroku create example
Creating ⬢ example... done
https://example.herokuapp.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/example.git

content_resolved.code:
$ heroku create example
Creating ⬢ example... done
https://example.herokuapp.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/example.git

title: The first URL of the ouput, http://example.herokuapp.com, is the location the app is available at. The second URL, git@heroku.com:example.git, is the remote git repository URL.

inline_content.Text: The first URL of the ouput, http://example.herokuapp.com, is the location the app is available at. The second URL, git@heroku.com:example.git, is the remote git repository URL.

title: This command should only be used on an initialized git repository. The heroku create command automatically adds a git remote named “heroku” pointing at this URL.

inline_content.Text: This command should only be used on an initialized git repository. The heroku create command automatically adds a git remote named “heroku” pointing at this URL.

title: The app name argument (“example”) is optional. If no app name is specified, a random name will be generated. Since Heroku app names are in a global namespace, you can expect that common names, like “blog” or “wiki”, will already be taken. It’s often easier to start with a default name and rename the app later.

inline_content.Text: The app name argument (“example”) is optional. If no app name is specified, a random name will be generated. Since Heroku app names are in a global namespace, you can expect that common names, like “blog” or “wiki”, will already be taken. It’s often easier to start with a default name and rename the app later.

title: Next, deploy your code:

title: If you are using the database in your application you need to manually migrate the database by running:

inline_content.Text: If you are using the database in your application you need to manually migrate the database by running:

title: $ heroku run rake db:migrate
Any commands after
heroku run
c
will be executed on a Heroku dyno. You can obtain an interactive shell session by running:

inline_content.Text: will be executed on a Heroku dyno. You can obtain an interactive shell session by running:

title: $ heroku run bash
Ensure you have one dyno running the web process type:

inline_content.Text: Ensure you have one dyno running the web process type:

title: $ heroku ps:scale web=1
The heroku ps command lists the running dynos of your application:

inline_content.Text: The heroku ps command lists the running dynos of your application:

title:
$ heroku ps
=== web (Standard-1X): bin/rails server -p $PORT -e $RAILS_ENV (1)
web.1: starting 2016/07/08 12:09:06 -0500 (~ 2s ago)

content_resolved.code:
$ heroku ps
=== web (Standard-1X): bin/rails server -p $PORT -e $RAILS_ENV (1)
web.1: starting 2016/07/08 12:09:06 -0500 (~ 2s ago)

title: You can now visit the app in our browser with
heroku open
c

inline_content.Text: You can now visit the app in our browser with

title: $ heroku open
Heroku gives you a default web URL in the
herokuapp.com
c
domain. When you are ready to scale up for production, you can add your own custom domain.

inline_content.Text: Heroku gives you a default web URL in the
domain. When you are ready to scale up for production, you can add your own custom domain.
